adverb.description: To the utmost or most absolute extent or degree; absolutely; completely.
examples: it's quite out of the question
are you quite certain about this?
this is quite a different problem
quite frankly, I don't blame you

adverb.description: To a certain or fairly significant extent or degree; fairly.
examples: she did quite well at school

exclamation.description: Expressing agreement with or understanding of a remark or statement.
examples: “I don't want to talk about that now.” “Quite.”

phrases: she hasn't quite got the hang of it yet
It's not quite leaping a tall building in a single bound, but it's the next best thing.
If it has not quite been able to reach its goal, it does not seem to be from lack of effort.
It was one of those mornings when you half wake up but not quite all the way.
origin: Middle English: from the obsolete adjective quite, variant of quit.
